title: Evaluating the Suitability of Different Intraoral Scan Resolutions for Deep Learning-Based Tooth Segmentation
author: Daron Weekley (Marshall University), Jace Duckworth (Marshall University), Anastasiia Sukhanova (Marshall University), Ananya Jana (Marshall University), ...
relevance_why: The methodology of using deep learning for segmentation in intraoral scans may provide insights into similar applications or adaptations in audio processing tasks.
background: This study investigates how varying resolutions of intraoral scans impact the performance of a deep learning model trained for tooth segmentation.
contribution: This paper introduces a systematic evaluation of the impact of mesh resolution on segmentation accuracy, achieving insights that balance computational efficiency with accuracy.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous studies generally trained models on fixed lower resolutions without extensively analyzing the effects on segmentation accuracy.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work explicitly evaluates the performance trajectory as resolutions decrease below 10K mesh cells, providing detailed performance metrics across resolutions.

key_innovation: It systematically compares the segmentation accuracy achieved at multiple resolutions, detailing the trade-offs between performance and computational demand for various applications.
real_world_impact: The findings may influence how dental practitioners adopt machine learning solutions for automated tooth segmentation, potentially leading to faster and more efficient workflows in digital dentistry.
limitations: The study is constrained by the singular focus on the PointMLP model and does not explore other architectures or datasets.

new_terms.mesh cells: **Mesh cells** are the basic units that make up a 3D model in computer graphics, typically formed by interconnected triangular facets representing surface geometry.
